Title: Real Time Ai Driven Assessment and Scaffolding That Improves Students’ Mathematical Modeling During Science Investigations
Exclusion Reason: Not applicable (the paper meets all inclusion criteria).
1.1 Primary Stakeholders - Source: "Participants included 70 students across four eighth grade science classes taught by the same teacher from the same school..." (Section 2.1, page 204).
1.2 Context - Source: "Students completed two Inq-ITS mathematical modeling virtual labs during their regularly scheduled classes." (Section 2.1, page 204).
1.3 Tech/AI type - Source: "We present the design and initial classroom test of AI-scaffolded virtual labs that help students practice these competencies." (Abstract, page 202).
1.4 Tool/Platform - Source: "In this paper, we evaluate the design of virtual labs in the Inquiry Intelligent Tutoring System (Inq-ITS)..." (Section 1, page 203).
1.5 Education level - Source: "Participants included 70 students across four eighth grade science classes..." (Section 2.1, page 204).
2.1 Feedback term - Source: "The labs automatically assess fine-grained sub-components of students’ mathematical modeling competencies based on the actions they take to build their mathematical models..." (Abstract, page 202).
2.2 Description of context: Feedback is provided in real-time as students work through virtual labs, with scaffolding triggered by their performance on specific tasks.
2.2 Description of context - Source: "If the student completes the task correctly (i.e., receives 1 for all sub-practices), they can proceed to the next stage. If not, individualized scaffolding is automatically triggered..." (Section 2.3, page 208).
2.3 Our evaluation: The feedback provided is targeted and specific, addressing the individual difficulties students face in mathematical modeling.
2.3 Our evaluation - Source: "This proactive approach was chosen because students often cannot recognize when to ask for help..." (Section 2.3, page 208).
3.1 Agency type: Limited student agency; students receive scaffolding based on their performance.
3.1 Agency type - Source: "Students also have the option to ask further predefined questions to the agent to receive definitions for key terms..." (Section 2.3, page 209).
3.2 Feedback timing control: Students do not control feedback timing; it is provided based on their performance.
3.2 Feedback timing control - Source: "Individualized scaffolding is automatically triggered based on the sub-practices on which the student was correct or incorrect..." (Section 2.3, page 208).
4.1 Metrics for evaluation: Average scores of sub-practice competencies before and after scaffolding.
4.1 Metrics for evaluation - Source: "To measure students’ competencies, students’ stage scores are calculated as the average of the sub-practice scores for that stage..." (Section 2.4, page 210).

Title: Enhancing Formative Assessment in Statistics Through Classroom Action Research
1.1 Primary Stakeholders: Students and instructors in a higher education statistics class.
1.1 Primary Stakeholders - Source: "The formative assessments developed were administered asynchronously, where students were initially given 7 days to answer each activity at their convenience." (Methods and action plan, p. 386)
1.2 Context: Higher education statistics class during the COVID-19 pandemic.
1.2 Context - Source: "This study is rooted in my multi-disciplinary three-unit statistics class at a private higher education institution in the Philippines." (Context of the study, p. 382)
1.3 Tech/AI type - Source: "One of the web-based technologies is the Learning Management System (LMS), which is intended to improve education delivery by assisting instructors in managing activities online." (Introduction, p. 382)
1.4 Tool/Platform - Source: "We opted for adopting MyOpenMath as our platform primarily because it has all the functions we needed." (Methods and action plan, p. 386)
1.5 Education level - Source: "The class has 33 student participants, 19 males and 14 females, with an average age of 18.54." (Methods and action plan, p. 386)
2.1 Feedback term - Source: "We deemed it necessary to incorporate immediate feedback per item in the formative assessment that we were designing." (Action implementation: formative assessment development, p. 388)
2.2 Description of context: Formative assessments were delivered asynchronously through the LMS, allowing students to practice statistical exercises and receive immediate feedback on their answers.
2.2 Description of context - Source: "Using LMS allowed me to administer formative assessments that can be automatically administered, retrieved, and graded." (Context of the study, p. 383)
2.3 Our evaluation: The feedback provided was immediate and aimed to correct misconceptions, which aligns with the purpose of formative assessment.
2.3 Our evaluation - Source: "The immediate feedback from the system motivated them to identify their mistakes and strive to get the correct answer." (Concluding remarks, p. 392)
3.1 Agency type: Student agency in controlling the timing and attempts of their assessments.
3.1 Agency type - Source: "The formative assessment allowed students to assess themselves and find ways to improve in the course." (Reflection and insights, p. 391)
3.2 Feedback timing control: Yes, students could control the timing of their feedback by re-attempting questions.
3.2 Feedback timing control - Source: "We structured the formative assessment items to allow students 100 tries (the limit of MyOpenMath) to reattempt problems they missed." (Action implementation: formative assessment development, p. 388)
4.1 Metrics for evaluation: Student reflections, average number of attempts, and time spent per attempt.
4.1 Metrics for evaluation - Source: "We note the average number of attempts and average time students spent per attempt in the formative assessments through the data analytics of MyOpenMath." (Action evaluation: utilization of LMS-supported formative assessment, p. 390)
4.2 Measurement of agency: Agency was measured through student reflections on their learning experiences and their ability to manage their assessment attempts.
4.2 Measurement of agency - Source: "Students expressed that they appreciate that they can partially answer the activity, take a break, and return to where they left off." (Action evaluation: utilization of LMS-supported formative assessment, p. 390)

Title: Analyzing Students’ Performance in Computerized Formative Assessments to Optimize Teachers’ Test Administration Decisions Using Deep Learning Frameworks
1.1 Primary Stakeholders - Source: "the proposed system would greatly help teachers make more systematic and informed test administration decisions" (Introduction, p. 72).
1.2 Context: Classroom setting with computerized formative assessments.
1.2 Context - Source: "computerized formative assessments in the classroom allows teachers to assess students’ learning continuously and more frequently" (Introduction, p. 72).
1.3 Tech/AI type: Deep learning frameworks, specifically Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) networks.
1.3 Tech/AI type - Source: "we introduced a deep learning framework to predict and optimize the number of test administrations" (Introduction, p. 72).
1.4 Tool/Platform - Source: "the dataset used in the study was collected from Star Math—a well-known formative assessment used for screening and progress monitoring purposes" (Methods, p. 78).
1.5 Education level - Source: "performance scores of 10,107 students in grade 1" (Methods, p. 78).
2.1 Feedback term - Source: "Not specified" (Not applicable).
2.2 Description of context: The feedback mechanism involves predicting the optimal number of test administrations based on students' performance data.
2.2 Description of context - Source: "the purpose of the current study was to introduce a systematic and automatic framework that could detect the students’ learning progress to determine whether more test administrations are required in math formative assessments" (Discussion and conclusion, p. 89).
2.3 Our evaluation: The feedback provided is predictive in nature, aimed at optimizing test administration rather than traditional feedback mechanisms.
2.3 Our evaluation - Source: "our model could successfully predict the test administration decision with a relatively short sequence of previous performance scores" (Discussion and conclusion, p. 89).
3.1 Agency type: Teacher agency in decision-making regarding test administration.
3.1 Agency type - Source: "teachers are expected to monitor 20–30 students’ academic progress" (Introduction, p. 73).
3.2 Feedback timing control: Not specified.
3.2 Feedback timing control - Source: "Not specified" (Not applicable).
4.1 Metrics for evaluation: Accuracy, precision, recall, and F1-score.
4.1 Metrics for evaluation - Source: "we used commonly employed classification accuracy metrics, such as the average accuracy, precision, recall, and F1-score" (Methods, p. 80).

Title: Enhancing Students ' Preparation for Math Exams Using the Advanced Features of the Halomda Platform
1.1 Primary Stakeholders - Source: "the goal is to discuss how to enhance students’ self-preparation for math exam" (Introduction, page 1).
1.2 Context - Source: "students' preparation for mathematics exams is very important" (Introduction, page 1).
1.3 Tech/AI type - Source: "the Halomda platform provides students with active feedback during the solution of the current task" (Section 3, page 24).
1.4 Tool/Platform - Source: "The Halomda platform (halomda.org) was established in 1988 in Israel" (Section 2, page 23).
1.5 Education level - Source: "students often read rapidly to cover as much material as possible" (Introduction, page 1).
2.1 Feedback term - Source: "the system provides different type of comments in a case of wrong answer" (Section 3, page 24).
2.2 Description of context: Feedback is provided during problem-solving, with options for students to receive help from AI or other tools.
2.2 Description of context - Source: "the system proposes the students to get some advice from ChatGPT" (Section 3, page 24).
2.3 Our evaluation: The feedback provided is interactive and aims to guide students through their learning process, enhancing understanding rather than just providing answers.
2.3 Our evaluation - Source: "active feedback from the system, together with the built-in tool, contributes to the sustainability of students’ knowledge" (Section 5, page 26).
3.1 Agency type: Self-directed learning agency.
3.1 Agency type - Source: "students have two options – recall the integration by parts formula using ChatGPT" (Section 4, page 25).
3.2 Feedback timing control: Students can control when they receive feedback during their problem-solving process.
3.2 Feedback timing control - Source: "students receive various type of help or are forced to select a result" (Section 4, page 25).
4.1 Metrics for evaluation: Improvement in self-efficacy and exam performance.
4.1 Metrics for evaluation - Source: "leading to a subsequent enhancement of their self-efficacy in mathematics" (Introduction, page 1).

Title: Algebra Error Classification with Large Language Models
1.1 Primary Stakeholders - Source: "This component enables teachers to provide personalized feedback at scale, since they can write feedback once that applies to many students." (Introduction, page 366)
1.2 Context - Source: Not specified
1.3 Tech/AI type - Source: "We propose a method that overcomes the above limitations by using pre-trained Large Language Models (LLMs) for algebra error classification." (Contributions, page 366)
1.4 Tool/Platform - Source: "The dataset contains logs of students’ step-by-step responses to questions in an Algebra I course... during student interactions with an ITS named Cognitive Tutor." (Experimental Evaluation, page 369)
1.5 Education level - Source: "We consider a question from an introduction to algebra class." (Methodology, page 367)
2.1 Feedback term - Source: "The feedback messages vary in length from short hints, such as 'Check your sign.' to more descriptive feedback, such as 'You are dividing a positive by a negative. The result should be negative'." (Experimental Evaluation, page 369)
2.2 Description of context: Feedback is generated based on detected student errors during the problem-solving process.
2.2 Description of context - Source: "Once detected, the error class then informs the feedback generator which feedback is appropriate to provide to the student." (Introduction, page 366)
2.3 Our evaluation: The feedback provided is immediate and tailored to specific errors, enhancing learning.
2.3 Our evaluation - Source: "This direct, timely feedback enables immediate learning and helps students refine their math skills at their own pace." (Introduction, page 366)
3.1 Agency type: Limited student agency; feedback is predefined and based on error classification.
3.1 Agency type - Source: "This is especially important for open-ended math questions, where students have to reason step-by-step and one error can lead a student away from the correct solution." (Introduction, page 366)
3.2 Feedback timing control: Students do not control feedback timing; feedback is provided based on error detection.
3.2 Feedback timing control - Source: "In these cases, the ITS showed an automated feedback message to the student indicating an error made during the equation-solving process." (Experimental Evaluation, page 369)
4.1 Metrics for evaluation: Classification accuracy.
4.1 Metrics for evaluation - Source: "For error classification, our primary metric is classification accuracy, i.e., percentage of correctly predicted classes in the test set." (Experimental Evaluation, page 370)

Title: “i Didn’t Understand, I´m Really Not Very Smart”—how Design of a Digital Tutee’s Self Efficacy Affects Conversation and Student Behavior in a Digital Math Game
Exclusion Reason: Not applicable (the paper meets the inclusion criteria).
1.1 Primary Stakeholders - Source: "we explore the effects of designing a pedagogical agent’s self-efficacy in order to see what effects this has on students’ interaction with it." (Introduction, page 1)
1.2 Context: The context is a digital math game where students interact with a digital tutee.
1.2 Context - Source: "We have analyzed chat logs from an educational math game incorporating an agent, which acts as a digital tutee." (Abstract, page 1)
1.3 Tech/AI type - Source: "Our digital tutee also belongs to the pedagogical agent subgroup called conversational pedagogical agents." (Section 1.1, page 3)
1.4 Tool/Platform - Source: "The math game 'The Squares Family' trains basic arithmetic skills related to the base-ten concept." (Section 2.1, page 5)
1.5 Education level - Source: "In total, 166 fourth graders (83 girls and 83 boys) participated in the data collection." (Section 2.3, page 10)
2.1 Feedback term - Source: "This type of feedback is what [29] call recursive feedback, namely feedback that occurs when the tutor observes her students use what she has taught them." (Section 1.1, page 3)
2.2 Description of context: Feedback is provided through chat after game sessions, reflecting the digital tutee's self-efficacy.
2.2 Description of context - Source: "The chat always started with a feedback-sentence that expressed the digital tutee’s self-efficacy (high or low)." (Section 2.1.1, page 6)
2.3 Our evaluation: The feedback provided by the digital tutee is designed to influence student engagement and self-efficacy positively.
2.3 Our evaluation - Source: "Students responded more frequently to feedback from a digital tutee with low self-efficacy, and these responses were mostly positive." (Results, page 13)
3.1 Agency type: Student agency is present as students interact with and teach the digital tutee.
3.1 Agency type - Source: "By teaching the agent, the student at the same time learns for herself." (Section 1.1, page 3)
3.2 Feedback timing control: Students do not control the timing of feedback; it is provided after game sessions.
3.2 Feedback timing control - Source: "The chat appeared after every finished game." (Section 2.1.1, page 6)
4.1 Metrics for evaluation: Frequency of responses to feedback and performance on multiple-choice questions.
4.1 Metrics for evaluation - Source: "To measure the students’ responses to the feedback provided by the tutee we used the code 'AnswerToFeedback' (AFB)." (Section 2.5.1, page 11)
4.2 Measurement of agency: Agency is measured through the students' interactions and comments during the chat.
4.2 Measurement of agency - Source: "The comments in question appeared in the free conversation following the feedback from the digital tutee." (Results, page 13)

Title: Development of a Generative Ai Powered Teachable Agent for Middle School Mathematics Learning a Design Based Research Study
1.1 Primary Stakeholders - Source: "The three empirical studies involved a total of 320 middle school students and six teachers in authentic classroom settings." (Introduction, p. 2043)
1.2 Context - Source: "This study chronicles one usability testing and three cycles of iterative design and implementation process of ALTER-Math." (Introduction, p. 2043)
1.3 Tech/AI type - Source: "This study designed and developed a generative AI-powered teachable agent to support secondary school students' mathematics learning." (Introduction, p. 2043)
1.4 Tool/Platform - Source: "We name the generative AI-powered teachable agent for mathematics learning ALTER-Math." (Introduction, p. 2043)
1.5 Education level - Source: "This study designed and developed a generative AI-powered teachable agent to support secondary school students' mathematics learning." (Introduction, p. 2043)
2.1 Feedback term - Source: "This feedback can take various forms, such as quizzes, simulations or real-world tasks that the agent attempts to complete based on the instruction it has received." (Teachable agent, p. 2046)
2.2 Description of context: Feedback is provided as students teach the agent, reflecting their understanding and effectiveness.
2.2 Description of context - Source: "As students teach the agent, the system provides feedback on the agent's performance, which indirectly reflects the student's teaching effectiveness and understanding of the subject matter." (Teachable agent, p. 2046)
2.3 Our evaluation: The feedback mechanism aligns with the learning-by-teaching approach, enhancing understanding through teaching.
2.3 Our evaluation - Source: "This promotes self-regulated learning by involving students in the active teaching of the agent, naturally leading them to organise, monitor and evaluate their own learning progress." (Teachable agent, p. 2046)
3.1 Agency type: Student agency through teaching the AI agent.
3.1 Agency type - Source: "Learning by teaching is realised in different formats, such as peer tutoring, where students engage in one-on-one or one-on-multiple tutoring sessions to teach younger or less knowledgeable peers." (Theoretical framework, p. 2048)
3.2 Feedback timing control: Students control the timing of feedback through their interactions with the agent.
3.2 Feedback timing control - Source: "Students' teachable agent would gain different points based on their selected difficulty level and types of interaction." (Design and development of ALTER-Math, p. 2052)
4.1 Metrics for evaluation: Pre- and post-knowledge tests, usability surveys, and qualitative feedback.
4.1 Metrics for evaluation - Source: "The final study included pre- and post- knowledge tests in a quasi-experimental study design as well as student and teacher interviews." (Methods, p. 2050)
4.2 Measurement of agency: Agency is measured through students' ability to teach the agent and their reflections on the teaching process.
4.2 Measurement of agency - Source: "This allows students to practice in authentic contexts and receive timely, relevant explanations." (Teachable agent, p. 2046)

Title: Stimulating Individual Learning of the Concept of Fraction Equivalence
1.1 Primary Stakeholders - Source: "Participants were 300 sixth-grade students from secondary schools in Germany." (Method, page 4)
1.2 Context: Classroom setting during a mathematics lesson focused on fractions.
1.2 Context - Source: "The study was conducted at the beginning of the school year 2022/2023." (Method, page 5)
1.3 Tech/AI type - Source: "The experimental group used an adaptive digital learning environment for practice." (Method, page 4)
1.4 Tool/Platform - Source: "The digital learning environment offers three tasks...". (Material, page 6)
1.5 Education level - Source: "The instruction of equivalent fractions in our study is grounded in Bruner’s (1960) theory on the levels of representation." (Method, page 5)
2.1 Feedback term - Source: "The digital learning environment provides individualized adaptive feedback and difficulty levels based on real-time process data." (Material, page 6)
2.2 Description of context: Feedback is provided based on students' performance, adjusting task difficulty and offering explanations for errors.
2.2 Description of context - Source: "The feedback is based on scientific recommendations... which include a combination of positive reinforcement and explanatory feedback." (Material, page 6)
2.3 Our evaluation: The feedback provided is both corrective and explanatory, aimed at enhancing understanding of fractions.
2.3 Our evaluation - Source: "Explanatory feedback... is designed to provide both correctness verification and targeted guidance to support conceptual understanding." (Material, page 6)
3.1 Agency type: Student agency is present as students can control their learning pace and task selection.
3.1 Agency type - Source: "Students perceive themselves as competent in their ability to cope with the demands of their environment." (Discussion, page 14)
3.2 Feedback timing control: Students do not control the timing of feedback; it is provided based on their performance in real-time.
3.2 Feedback timing control - Source: "The subsequent set is generated from the next higher level—otherwise, the user remains at the same level." (Material, page 6)
4.1 Metrics for evaluation: Performance scores on fraction tasks and self-reported measures of engagement.
4.1 Metrics for evaluation - Source: "The assessment test of equivalent fractions performance in the posttest consisted of questions regarding conceptual aspects of expanding and reducing fractions." (Method, page 8)
4.2 Measurement of agency: Agency is measured through self-reported perceptions of competence and autonomy support.
4.2 Measurement of agency - Source: "We operationalized students’ motivational and emotional orientations regarding mathematics in general as a trait assessment with self-reports." (Method, page 8)

Title: Work in Progress Investigating Chatgpt for Grading Algebra Problems
Exclusion Reason: Not applicable, as the paper meets the inclusion criteria.

1.2 Context: Classroom setting within an algebra course.
1.2 Context - Source: "This study investigates the feasibility of integrating ChatGPT as an AI-driven grading tool in an algebra course through a pilot implementation within a structured learning environment." (Section II, METHODOLOGY)
1.3 Tech/AI type - Source: "This study investigates the feasibility of integrating ChatGPT, an advanced AI language model, as a grading tool for algebra problems." (Section I, INTRODUCTION)
1.4 Tool/Platform - Source: "Experimental Group: Students whose assignments are graded using AI-generated feedback." (Section II, METHODOLOGY)
1.5 Education level - Source: "The study will be conducted within an undergraduate algebra course, ensuring a representative sample of students." (Section II, METHODOLOGY)
2.1 Feedback term - Source: "The experimental group will receive AI-generated feedback, while traditional instructors will grade the control group." (Section II, METHODOLOGY)
2.2 Description of context: Feedback is provided after students submit their algebra problems, with structured prompts to replicate classroom grading conditions.
2.2 Description of context - Source: "Each prompt includes the algebra problem, the student’s submission, and a request for detailed feedback." (Section II, METHODOLOGY)
2.3 Our evaluation: The feedback provided by ChatGPT is intended to be constructive, aiming to improve student understanding, though its effectiveness may vary.
2.3 Our evaluation - Source: "The findings will contribute to ongoing discussions on AI’s role in educational assessment and inform future implementations of AI-driven grading systems." (Section I, INTRODUCTION)
3.1 Agency type: Limited student agency in feedback timing; feedback is provided after submission.
3.1 Agency type - Source: "The experimental group will receive AI-generated feedback, while traditional instructors will grade the control group." (Section II, METHODOLOGY)
3.2 Feedback timing control: Students do not control feedback timing; feedback is given post-submission.
3.2 Feedback timing control - Source: "The experimental group will receive AI-generated feedback, while traditional instructors will grade the control group." (Section II, METHODOLOGY)
4.1 Metrics for evaluation: Accuracy, precision, recall, F1-score, and qualitative assessments of feedback clarity and relevance.
4.1 Metrics for evaluation - Source: "Quantitative metrics include: Accuracy: The percentage of ChatGPT’s assessments that match the expected assessment." (Section II, METHODOLOGY)

Title: “exceptional Talent and Enthusiasm for Math” an Examination of Storylines Circulated by Chatgpt About Mathematical Learners
Exclusion Reason: Not applicable (the paper meets the inclusion criteria).
1.1 Primary Stakeholders - Source: "Professional organizations, such as the National Council for Teachers of Mathematics (NCTM, 2024), have advocated the benefits of AI powered tools to support teachers by reducing labor burdens, leveraging student interests, providing individualized feedback, and even serving as a 'teacher assistant'." (Introduction, page 1621)
1.2 Context - Source: "Given the rise in AI chatbots in education, the instructional burden of providing students with individualized math writing feedback..." (The Current Study, page 1625)
1.3 Tech/AI type - Source: "To understand how AI chatbots participate in such storylines, we examined ChatGPT’s feedback to different learners’ mathematical writing in an exploratory study." (Abstract, page 1620)
1.4 Tool/Platform - Source: "Data for this study was collected between April and July of 2023 from Open AI’s chatbot, ChatGPT 3.5." (Methods, page 1625)
1.5 Education level - Source: "We next told ChatGPT, 'You are now an elementary math teacher.'" (Methods, page 1625)
2.1 Feedback term - Source: "The feedback included: 1) greeting, 2) opening praise, 3) discussed mathematical content (2-3 paragraphs), 4) worked-out solution (if it identified the answer as wrong), 5) closing praise (1-2 paragraphs), 6) offer of ongoing support, and 7) signature." (Data Analysis, page 1626)
2.2 Description of context: Feedback is provided in a structured format, including praise and discussion of mathematical content, and is tailored based on the learner's characteristics.
2.2 Description of context - Source: "The feedback produced by ChatGPT when prompted to respond as a teacher had a predictable structure, which allowed us to easily compare iterations." (Data Analysis, page 1626)
2.3 Our evaluation: The feedback provided by ChatGPT reflects existing narratives and biases about different learners, which may not align with the actual capabilities of the students.
2.3 Our evaluation - Source: "While it is unlikely that a practicing teacher would elicit feedback from ChatGPT (or other AI chatbots) in the same manner we have, it is important for educators, teacher educators, and researchers to understand the extent that emergent AI tools have learned to participate in broader storylines about mathematical learners." (Discussion, page 1631)
3.1 Agency type: Limited student agency; feedback is primarily teacher-directed.
3.1 Agency type - Source: "ChatGPT does not appear to have rewritten, per se, feedback to each new student, but to have modified its previous feedback with apparently targeted changes and random variations." (Limitations and Future Research, page 1632)
3.2 Feedback timing control: Not specified; feedback is generated based on the input provided without indication of student control over timing.
3.2 Feedback timing control - Source: "At the time of data collection, it was not fully known whether or how previous interactions within one chat affect ChatGPT’s responses." (Methods, page 1625)
4.1 Metrics for evaluation: The study evaluates the quality of feedback based on its alignment with existing narratives and the effectiveness of the feedback structure.
4.1 Metrics for evaluation - Source: "We used positioning theory as our conceptual framework... to analyze the data." (Data Analysis, page 1626)
4.2 Measurement of agency: Not specified; the paper does not detail how agency is measured.

Title: Constraint Based Student Modelling in Probability Story Problems with Scaffolding Techniques
1.1 Primary Stakeholders - Source: "The subjects of the test were students enrolled in the third secondary level in the Egyptian educational system." (Section 8.1, page 196)
1.2 Context: Classroom setting with a focus on probability story problems.
1.2 Context - Source: "MAST is a Web-based intelligent tutoring system for probability story problems." (Section 4, page 181)
1.3 Tech/AI type: Intelligent Tutoring System (ITS) utilizing Constraint-Based Modeling (CBM).
1.3 Tech/AI type - Source: "Constraint-Based student Modeling (CBM) is an important technique employed in intelligent tutoring systems to model student knowledge." (Section 1, page 178)
1.4 Tool/Platform - Source: "This paper introduces the Math Story Problem Tutor (MAST), a Web-based intelligent tutoring system for probability story problems." (Section 1, page 178)
1.5 Education level - Source: "The subjects of the test were students enrolled in the third secondary level in the Egyptian educational system." (Section 8.1, page 196)
2.1 Feedback term: Scaffolding feedback, hints, and keywords highlighting.
2.1 Feedback term - Source: "MAST exploits both scaffolding questions and scaffolding feedback." (Section 7, page 194)
2.2 Description of context: Feedback is provided through highlighting keywords and scaffolding questions to guide students in solving probability problems.
2.2 Description of context - Source: "MAST provides different levels of feedback. It starts by presenting a clue to the student by highlighting the related violated constraint keywords." (Section 7.2, page 195)
2.3 Our evaluation: The feedback provided is specific and targeted, aiming to help students understand their errors and correct them effectively.
2.3 Our evaluation - Source: "MAST introduces visual hints to the student in addition to the general feedback." (Section 7.2, page 195)
3.1 Agency type: Limited student agency; students can request hints and control some aspects of their learning process.
3.1 Agency type - Source: "In case of an error in the event set representation question, the student may request help by requesting a hint." (Section 7.2, page 195)
3.2 Feedback timing control: Students have some control over when they receive feedback, especially through requesting hints.
3.2 Feedback timing control - Source: "In case of an error in the event set representation question, the student may request help by requesting a hint." (Section 7.2, page 195)
4.1 Metrics for evaluation: Paired samples t-test, normalized knowledge gain, Mann-Whitney U test, and power learning curves.
4.1 Metrics for evaluation - Source: "The tutoring effect of MAST has been evaluated empirically using different tests (paired samples t-test, normalized knowledge gain, Mann-Whitney U test, and power learning curves)." (Section 1, page 178)
4.2 Measurement of agency: Agency is measured through student interactions with the system, including their ability to request hints and the tracking of their answers and errors.
4.2 Measurement of agency - Source: "A student model database stores all the student logs regarding the selected problem types and the presented statements." (Section 6, page 192)

Title: Effectiveness and Guidance of Artificial Intelligence Chatbots in Diagnosing Exponential Expression Errors
Exclusion Reason: Not applicable (the paper meets all inclusion criteria).
1.1 Primary Stakeholders - Source: "the study recommends the integration of synchronous and asynchronous classroom environments in which teachers can closely monitor student responses." (Introduction, p. 548)
1.2 Context - Source: "the study seeks to assess whether students, without direct teacher support, can recognize and potentially correct their misconceptions with the help of chatbots in informal learning settings." (Purpose and contribution of the study, p. 552)
1.3 Tech/AI type - Source: "the primary rationale for selecting ChatGPT and Gemini in this study lies in the fact that both models are current, powerful, widely accessible, and possess distinct technical capabilities." (Purpose and contribution of the study, p. 552)
1.4 Tool/Platform - Source: "the study aims to analyze how students mentally represent and structure their understanding of exponential expressions and to categorize these representations into meaningful classifications." (Purpose and contribution of the study, p. 552)
1.5 Education level - Source: "the items in the administered test cover learning outcomes related to exponential expressions in the 8th-grade mathematics curriculum." (Data collection tool, p. 553)
2.1 Feedback term - Source: "the study investigates the potential of generative AI-based chatbots—namely ChatGPT and Gemini—to identify students’ misconceptions regarding exponential expressions and to guide them in correcting these misconceptions." (Purpose and contribution of the study, p. 552)
2.2 Description of context: Chatbots analyze student responses and provide feedback based on misconceptions.
2.2 Description of context - Source: "the guidance-oriented feedback provided by ChatGPT-4 and Gemini was analyzed alongside the students’ responses." (Findings regarding the guidance provided by ChatGPT-4 and Gemini Chatbots in addressing student misconceptions, p. 556)
2.3 Our evaluation: The chatbots provide varying levels of effective guidance, with ChatGPT-4 generally outperforming Gemini in classifying responses.
2.3 Our evaluation - Source: "ChatGPT demonstrated a higher level of accuracy in classifying student responses compared to the Gemini system." (Findings regarding the effectiveness of ChatGPT-4 and Gemini chatbots in identifying misconceptions in exponential expressions, p. 556)
3.1 Agency type: Limited student agency; students interact with chatbots for feedback.
3.1 Agency type - Source: "students were asked to share their solutions for each question with AI-supported chatbots and to proceed based on the feedback they received from the bots." (Data collection and analysis, p. 553)
3.2 Feedback timing control: Students do not control feedback timing; feedback is provided after responses.
3.2 Feedback timing control - Source: "students were asked to share their solutions for each question with AI-supported chatbots and to proceed based on the feedback they received from the bots." (Data collection and analysis, p. 553)
4.1 Metrics for evaluation: Classification of student responses into categories such as correct knowledge, lack of confidence, lack of knowledge, and misconception.
4.1 Metrics for evaluation - Source: "the responses were categorized as correct knowledge, lack of confidence, lack of knowledge, or misconception." (Data collection and analysis, p. 553)

Title: Contextual Factors Affecting Hint Utility
1.1 Primary Stakeholders - Source: "The system was designed primarily for middle school mathematics and allows teachers to easily create and assign their own problem sets..." (Background section, page 2)
1.2 Context - Source: "The RCTs in this study were implemented in the ASSISTments online learning system..." (Methods section, page 3)
1.3 Tech/AI type - Source: "This work aims to further the state-of-the-art in intelligent tutoring systems..." (Background section, page 2)
1.4 Tool/Platform - Source: "The RCTs in this study were implemented in the ASSISTments online learning system..." (Methods section, page 3)
1.5 Education level - Source: "The system was designed primarily for middle school mathematics..." (Background section, page 2)
2.1 Feedback term - Source: "Hints, for example, help students recall relevant concepts, identify mistakes, and make inferences." (Background section, page 2)
2.2 Description of context: Feedback is provided through on-demand hints during problem-solving in an online mathematics assignment.
2.2 Description of context - Source: "The treatment group was able to request a series of progressive hints, while the control group was only able to access a bottom-out hint..." (Methods section, page 3)
2.3 Our evaluation: The feedback provided is adaptive, as it allows students to request hints based on their needs during problem-solving.
2.3 Our evaluation - Source: "Students in the HE condition were naturally more likely to ask for regular hints because they had early access to hints." (Results section, page 8)
3.1 Agency type: Student agency in seeking help.
3.1 Agency type - Source: "Help-seeking behavior can be measured by the frequency of hint requests..." (Working model section, page 10)
3.2 Feedback timing control: Students control the timing of feedback by requesting hints.
3.2 Feedback timing control - Source: "Students assigned to the HE condition were allowed to request on-demand hints throughout the full assignment." (Methods section, page 3)
4.1 Metrics for evaluation: Mastery speed, percent correct, and attrition.
4.1 Metrics for evaluation - Source: "Student performance can be measured by mastery speed, percent correct, and attrition..." (Discussion section, page 11)
4.2 Measurement of agency: Agency is measured through the frequency of hint requests and the type of hints requested.
4.2 Measurement of agency - Source: "Requesting regular hints alone compared to requesting a bottom-out hint may indicate higher levels of self-efficacy..." (Working model section, page 10)

Title: Incentivizing Supplemental Math Assignments and Using Ai Generated Hints Is Associated with Improved Exam Performance
Exclusion Reason: Not applicable (the paper meets all inclusion criteria).
1.1 Primary Stakeholders - Source: "The students participating in the study were enrolled in one of two sections... Both sections were taught by the same instructor." (Section II, Methods)
1.2 Context: Introductory physics course at a large public university.
1.2 Context - Source: "The study was carried out at a large public university in the Southwestern United States." (Section II, Methods)
1.3 Tech/AI type: AI-generated hints integrated into homework assignments.
1.3 Tech/AI type - Source: "AI-generated learning support tools in the form of optional hints embedded in the physics homework assignments." (Section I, Introduction)
1.4 Tool/Platform - Source: "The AI-generated hints are integrated into the homework platform in Kudu." (Section I, Introduction)
1.5 Education level - Source: "These interventions... are therefore very promising for creating more equitable undergraduate quantitative courses." (Section I, Introduction)
2.1 Feedback term - Source: "AI-generated hints were integrated into the homework assignments." (Section I, Introduction)
2.2 Description of context: Feedback is provided through AI-generated hints that guide students in problem-solving without giving away full solutions.
2.2 Description of context - Source: "The AI-generated hints are designed to give qualitative descriptions on the essential steps toward solving a problem." (Appendix B)
2.3 Our evaluation: The feedback provided by AI-generated hints is supportive and aims to enhance problem-solving skills without directly providing answers.
2.3 Our evaluation - Source: "They are meant to guide students in the problem-solving process instead of completely giving away the answer." (Appendix B)
3.1 Agency type: Limited student agency; students can choose to use hints but are not required to.
3.1 Agency type - Source: "Students have unlimited attempts to use them for each question so that they can explore the most useful version." (Section II, Methods)
3.2 Feedback timing control: Students do not control the timing of feedback; hints are available when they attempt the homework.
3.2 Feedback timing control - Source: "When AI-generated hints are available, students have unlimited attempts to use them for each question." (Section II, Methods)
4.1 Metrics for evaluation: Exam scores, completion rates of supplemental math assignments, and usage of AI-generated hints.
4.1 Metrics for evaluation - Source: "Throughout the three periods of this study, we collected data on student homework scores, use of AI-generated hints on the homework problems, and completion of supplemental math materials." (Section II, Methods)
4.2 Measurement of agency: Agency is measured through the completion rates of supplemental math assignments and the usage of AI-generated hints.
4.2 Measurement of agency - Source: "To quantify factors that are associated with students’ completion of math materials, we performed a logistic regression." (Section II, Methods)

Title: Improving the Validity of Automatically Generated Feedback via Reinforcement Learning
1.1 Primary Stakeholders - Source: "We experiment on a dataset that consists of feedback messages written by math teachers for each incorrect option in multiple-choice questions." (Section 1, page 281)
1.2 Context - Source: Not specified
1.3 Tech/AI type: Large Language Models (LLMs) and Reinforcement Learning (RL).
1.3 Tech/AI type - Source: "We propose a framework for feedback generation that optimizes both correctness and alignment using reinforcement learning (RL)." (Section 1, page 281)
1.4 Tool/Platform - Source: "We primarily use the instruction-tuned Llama-2 7B Chat model from HuggingFace for feedback generation." (Section 4.2, page 287)
1.5 Education level - Source: "We validate our framework using a dataset of middle school-level math multiple choice questions." (Section 4.1, page 286)

2.2 Description of context - Source: "We propose a framework that both generates and evaluates feedback messages for incorrect student responses to questions, to improve both their correctness and alignment with educational goals." (Section 1, page 281)
2.3 Our evaluation: The feedback generated is aimed at being pedagogically valid and aligned with educational goals, focusing on both correctness and student misconceptions.
2.3 Our evaluation - Source: "Feedback content has to be valid especially in subjects like math, which requires models to understand the problem, the solution, and where the student’s error lies." (Section 1, page 281)

3.1 Agency type - Source: "Providing students with helpful feedback can be critical to their learning, allowing them to quickly address and learn from mistakes." (Section 1, page 281)
